Award.AwardTitle: CoLang 2016: Institute on Collaborative Language Research - ALASKA

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The 2016 Institute on Collaborative Language Research (CoLang 2016) will be held at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. CoLang brings together leading practitioners of language documentation from across the world to provide cutting-edge training in language documentation techniques and collaborative practices. Over a period of five weeks, including two weeks of workshops followed by three-week, in-depth field methods classes, participants engage in hands-on training in best practices in linguistic field research. Uniquely, CoLang focuses on collaborative documentation, engaging specialists from within language communities of underrepresented groups with academicians in knowledge sharing. All participants learn and teach, providing formal instruction via workshops or practicum teaching, participating in classes that take them out of their familiar areas and challenge them to engage with cultures and material new to them, and by networking with their colleagues around the world. In this way, CoLang builds a growing network of language workers who support each other in developing valid and sustainable approaches to language documentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the 2016 Institute on Collaborative Language Research (CoLang), held June-July, 2016, at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF).  CoLang brought together 56 leading practitioners of language documentation from around the world to provide cutting-edge training in language documentation techniques, collaborative practices, and language revitalization. Held over a period of five weeks, Colang 2016 began with two weeks of 34 six-hour workshops followed by three concurrent three-week, in-depth documentation practica on Han, Miyako, or Unangam Tunuu (Aleut). Practicum participants focused on best practices in linguistic field research, choosing one of the three languages.

The 106 participants included undergraduate and graduate students, academic linguists, and language community activists.

CoLang 2016 taught the basics of linguistics, documentation, technical resources and community engagement. All participants were either learners, academic linguists who want to gain technical skills, excellent undergraduate and graduate students from all types of programs, or language workers with careers in community language maintenance and revitalization, and all gained experience in capacity building. CoLang 2016 has so far resulted in 10 conference presentations, a short video  "CoLang 2016: World Language Documentation and Revitalization", two websites, a book chapter, improved infrastructure at the Alaska Native Language Archive, a spin off mini-CoLang institute in Okinawa, and full funding for 13 students to attend CoLang 2018 at the University of Florida.

CoLang brings about changes in the field of linguistics, adding value to description and documentation, focusing on responsibility to data and data management, and launching new fields of research such as the workshop Language and Wellness, co-taught by two linguists at CoLang 2016.

CoLang 2016 introduced several new topics to the curriculum: Community Language Archives, Cultural Impact in Community Linguistics, Documenting the Language of Landscape, Oral Annotation Methods, Spatial Visualization and Language Documentation, and Working with Archival Materials. Anna Berge's Unangam Tunuu practicum was also innovative in concentrating on archival materials while collaborating with an expert speaker.

Participants responding to a CoLang 2016 exit survey reported:

 

CoLang in Alaska (Alangska) has been the opportunity and experience of a lifetime for a young linguistics undergraduate from Singapore and I am extremely grateful to the organisers for just making this entire institute possible. Thank you for an amazing two weeks and please keep doing what you're doing because it has been just awesome being here and learning from all these wonderful people doing wonderful things.

I am so happy to have come to CoLang. Though I have been doing fieldwork and working with communities for years, I learned a lot, and had many "oh, why didn't I think of this 10 years ago?" moments. A great experience!

I think the best thing about CoLang is the variety of people you meet; people come from all sorts of linguistic, personal and professional backgrounds, but all with the same goal: community based language documentation. Next to the inspiration from the general atmosphere, I liked the software classes most for picking up practical skills, not only for myself, but also for being passed on to others in the community.
